description: Number of sequences s of length n with s[1]=1, s[2]=1, s[j-1]<s[j]<=s[j-2]+s[j-1] for j>=3.
comments: The sequences of length n that are counted here are sub-Fibonacci sequences (A005269) with the property that its members, except for the initial two terms, strictly increase. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 15 2007
references: Fishburn, Peter C. and Roberts, Fred S.; Elementary sequences, sub-Fibonacci sequences. Discrete Appl. Math. 44 (1993), no. 1-3, 261-281.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..70
formula: a(n) equals the number of nodes in generation n-2 of the sub-Fibonacci tree (A125051) for n>=2. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 19 2006See the Maple program; g[k](x, y) is the number of sequences s[1], s[2], ..., s[k+2] such that s[1]=x, s[2]=y, s[j-1] <s[j] <= s[j-2]+s[j-1] for j>=3. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 15 2007
maple: g[0]:=1:for k from 0 to 20 do g[k+1]:=expand(sum(subs({x=y, y=z}, g[k]), z=y+1..x+y)) od:seq(subs({x=1, y=1}, g[k]), k=0..20); # _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 15 2007
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
